data.text:
This is leadership. Marlene Engelhorn, who is 31 and lives in Vienna, wants 50 Austrians to determine how ‚Ç¨25m (¬£21.5m) of her inheritance should be redistributed. Engelhorn inherited the money from her family, who owns the chemical giant BASF. She wants her vast wealth to be redistributed across society and has campaigned for years for a more equitable tax system in her home country. "‚Ç¨25 million can be redistributed because the state does not redistribute it. I have this money because it is not taxed. I have this money because the government has failed to fulfill its mandate to ensure that wealth is distributed in society in such a way that it doesn't end up unequally in my hands just because I'm in this world, in this particular family, with this surname," Marlene Engelhorn said during a press conference Wednesday. The heiress has been urging the government to impose taxes on that money for many years. However, given Austria's absence of inheritance or wealth taxes, she sought an alternative solution: setting up a council to decide how the fortune would be distributed. A Citizens' Council comprising 50 individuals will be formed through a two-step process: 10,000 letters will be sent to residents, followed by the selection of 50 members and 15 substitutes. Eligibility requires members to be over 16 years old and representative of the population in Austria. The Council "Guter Rat f√ºr R√ºckverteilung", which means good advice for redistribution, will meet for six weekends from March until June and work on proposals to distribute the wealth. Marlene Engelhorn will not have any influence on the distribution. #thisisleadership #leadership https://lnkd.in/eX_2G-DK

Exploring the Essentials of Taxation in a Modern Economy: Taxation plays a crucial role in our economy, serving two primary purposes: funding government expenditure and influencing domestic economic management. Additionally, it serves as a tool to achieve various social objectives, impacting wealth distribution and encouraging specific behaviors. The UK tax system is designed to: 1. Incentivize individual savings and pension provision through tax incentives. 2. Support charitable donations via schemes like gift aid. 3. Encourage entrepreneurship and investment with targeted tax reliefs. Conversely, it discourages certain behaviors, such as motoring (fuel duties) and smoking/drinking (imposing taxes). Moreover, taxation policies contribute to "Green" initiatives, addressing climate change and promoting sustainability. Understanding the broader impact of taxation requires considering both direct and indirect taxes. Direct taxes, like income tax and corporation tax, are levied on income and capital transfers, while indirect taxes, such as VAT, are applied to goods and services.
